pullRequest.body:
Also change some lemmas to assume `[IsUnit _]` instead of `[Invertible _]`.

Motivated by potential non-defeq diamonds in #14986, see also [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Invertible.20and.20data)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [beeb1e7c4c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17458/commits/beeb1e7c4c2e3d14f64f05e10c1f4ee4385ddc4c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsAddUnit`
`+ instance (priority := 100) [NeZero a] : IsUnit a := .mk0 _ <| NeZero.ne _`
`+ instance (x : M) [Decidable (∃ u : Mˣ, ↑u = x)] : Decidable (IsUnit x)`
`+ instance [Nontrivial R] [IsUnit (2 : R)] : Nontrivial (CliffordAlgebra Q) := by`
`+ instance {X Y : C} (f : X ⟶ Y) [Epi f] (r : R) [IsUnit r] : Epi (r • f)`
`+ instance {X Y : C} (f : X ⟶ Y) [Mono f] (r : R) [IsUnit r] : Mono (r • f)`
`- _root_.IsAddUnit.addUnit`
`- instance (x : M) [h : Decidable (∃ u : Mˣ, ↑u = x)] : Decidable (IsUnit x)`
`- instance [Nontrivial R] [Invertible (2 : R)] :`
`- instance {X Y : C} (f : X ⟶ Y) [Epi f] (r : R) [Invertible r] : Epi (r • f)`
`- instance {X Y : C} (f : X ⟶ Y) [Mono f] (r : R) [Invertible r] : Mono (r • f)`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/a0cf1762-50dc-42d4-9d89-ee6b5fccd688) for commit bb4fe9782160285a5498001edda0910f1df6496c.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/9e32fb8c-7b0f-4104-9a96-089c7c726207/to/a0cf1762-50dc-42d4-9d89-ee6b5fccd688) against commit 5e050d47562fa4938a5f9afbc006c7f02f4544aa.

What's the situation where having this as a typeclass is useful? I agree that there are a handful of `Invertible`s in mathlib that might be better spelt `IsUnit`, but I don't see why we can't use `(h : IsUnit x)` in those places. What makes `IsUnit` typeclass-worthy when `Prime` is not?
For me, the main case is the instance `[Field K] [CharZero K] : IsUnit (2 : K)` (available via `NeZero`).
I don't understand what you mean; if you're writing theorems that take `[IsUnit 2]`, can't you just write them to take `(h : IsUnit 2)`?
Why not let TC search find it for me? We have `NeZero`, why not have `IsUnit`? P.S.: Should we continue on Zulip thread linked in the PR commit message?
Here is my personal opinion: any attempt to convert existing `Prop`/`Type` to `class` will break the old code using dot notation. Sometimes this will make existing code significantly longer.
As you can see, none of the dot notation uses is broken, only `rw [IsUnit]` is broken.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
However, sometimes we use it as a `Prop`-valued version of `Invertible`. -/
```

pullRequest.title: refactor(Algebra/Group): make `IsUnit` a typeclass

`+ IsAddUnit`

`+ instance {X Y : C} (f : X ⟶ Y) [Epi f] (r : R) [IsUnit r] : Epi (r • f)`

`- _root_.IsAddUnit.addUnit`

</details>
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/a0cf1762-50dc-42d4-9d89-ee6b5fccd688) for commit bb4fe9782160285a5498001edda0910f1df6496c.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/9e32fb8c-7b0f-4104-9a96-089c7c726207/to/a0cf1762-50dc-42d4-9d89-ee6b5fccd688) against commit 5e050d47562fa4938a5f9afbc006c7f02f4544aa.

What's the situation where having this as a typeclass is useful? I agree that there are a handful of `Invertible`s in mathlib that might be better spelt `IsUnit`, but I don't see why we can't use `(h : IsUnit x)` in those places. What makes `IsUnit` typeclass-worthy when `Prime` is not?
For me, the main case is the instance `[Field K] [CharZero K] : IsUnit (2 : K)` (available via `NeZero`).
I don't understand what you mean; if you're writing theorems that take `[IsUnit 2]`, can't you just write them to take `(h : IsUnit 2)`?
Why not let TC search find it for me? We have `NeZero`, why not have `IsUnit`? P.S.: Should we continue on Zulip thread linked in the PR commit message?
Here is my personal opinion: any attempt to convert existing `Prop`/`Type` to `class` will break the old code using dot notation. Sometimes this will make existing code significantly longer.
As you can see, none of the dot notation uses is broken, only `rw [IsUnit]` is broken.
